trial_identification.studytitle: Health-related quality of life in survivors of H1N1 (swine) influenza admitted to intensive care
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Patients admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with H1N1 influenza undergoing standard care including ICU and mechanical ventilation compared to the normal age and sex matched population and evaluating the effects on health-related quality of life.
trial_identification.secondaryid: Quality of life in H1N1 survivors admitted to ICU

conditions.healthcondition: Patients with H1N1 influenza and admission to ICU and undergoing mechanical ventilation

interventions.interventions:
The patients included in this trial have been exposed to H1N1 infection, admitted to an ICU and undergone a period of mechanical ventilation.
The health-related quality of life will be observed in these patients over a period of twelve months following ICU discharge (at six and twelve month time points).
Patients will undergo standard hospital and allied health care during and after their ICU admission, and this is usually delivered in a problem-based manner, this may not be standardized.
interventions.comparator:
Normative healthy age and sex matched population (1995 National Health Survey: SF-36 population norms, Australia. Canberra: Australian Bureau of Statistics; 1997).
The cohort will also be compared with other national and international HR-QoL following ICU data.
Dowdy DW, Eid MP, Sedrakyan A, et al. Quality of life in adult survivors of critical illness: a systematic review of the literature. Intensive Care Med. May 2005;31(5):611-620.
Boyle M, Murgo M, Adamson H, Gill J, Elliott D, Crawford M. The effect of chronic pain on health related quality of life amongst intensive care survivors. Aust Crit Care. Aug 2004;17(3):104-106, 108-113.
Elliott D, Mudaliar Y, Kim C. Examining discharge outcomes and health status of critically ill patients: some practical considerations. Intensive Crit Care Nurs. Dec 2004;20(6):366-377.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Health-related quality of life, measured by two HR-QoL questionnaires (the SF-36 Version 2 (Australian version) and the Assessment of Quality of Life (AQoL).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 6 and 12 months following discharge from the intensive care unit

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Return to work, assessed by telephone interview.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 6 and 12 months following discharge from the intensive care unit

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: H1N1 confirmed infection Age > 18 Admitted to ICU Undergoing intubation and mechanical ventilaton

othercollaborator.othercollaboratorname: Australian and New Zealand Intensive Care Society (ANZICS) Influenza Investigators
othercollaborator.othercollaboratoraddress: C/O Intensive Care Department Austin Health Studley Road Heidelberg Victoria, 3084

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Participants suffering H1N1 and requiring admission to an ICU and mechanical ventilation will be followed up after ICU discharge to prospectively record health-related quality of life 6 and 12 months following ICU discharge.
